intro: Libertia umbellata, commonly known as the mountain daffodil, is a flowering plant native to South America, particularly in regions of Chile and Argentina. It belongs to the Amaryllidaceae family and is characterized by its striking, bell-shaped flowers that range in color from white to yellow. The plant typically grows in rocky or mountainous environments, preferring well-drained soil and full sun exposure. Its bulbs are adapted to survive in harsh climates, and it blooms in the spring, making it a notable ornamental plant in gardens. The leaves are strap-like and evergreen, contributing to its aesthetic appeal throughout the growing season.
